item.title: Pelosi Leaves Taiwan, but Tensions Rise in Her Wake
item.description: The House speaker’s trip was celebrated on the island, but China warned of repercussions as it prepared for live-fire drills that would mark a direct challenge to Taiwan’s maritime claims.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi visiting Taiwan’s legislature in Taipei, the capital, on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Braces for Attack as Russian Troops Mass in South
item.description: As Ukraine has pushed forward around Kherson, Russia appears to be pouring forces in. With striking Republican support, the U.S. Senate voted to approve NATO’s expansion to include Finland and Sweden.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: Mexico’s Drought: Country Faces a Water Emergency
item.description: Nearly two-thirds of the country’s municipalities are facing a water shortage. In Monterrey, a major economic hub, the government delivers water daily to 400 neighborhoods.
item.dc:creator: Cesar Rodriguez, Maria Abi-Habib and Bryan Avelar

item.title: Sri Lanka Targets Protest Organizers That Toppled President
item.description: Activists involved in the protest movement have been arrested, but allies of the former president are back in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Sri Lanka where economic conditions are dire, protesters took control of the prime minister’s office last month.

item.title: Will an Investigation of a Former Mexican President Lead to Charges?
item.description: After years of promises, many Mexicans fear that the announcement of a corruption probe into Enrique Peña Nieto might be nothing more than a political tactic.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: The former Mexican president Enrique Peña Nieto was dogged by scandal during much of his six-year tenure.

item.title: For the Taliban, a New Era of Isolation Has Arrived
item.description: The group has promised moderation even while reinstituting its harsh rule of Afghanistan. Now, the revelation that the Taliban were sheltering Al Qaeda’s leader is likely to harden support for sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Taliban stand guard in the neighborhood where a U.S. drone strike killed the Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahiri.

item.title: What We Know About the Killing of Ayman al-Zawahri
item.description: The United States said it killed the Qaeda leader, an ally of Osama bin Laden who was considered a mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks. Here’s a guide to the drone strike and its implications.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Ayman al-Zawahri, then Al Qaeda’s deputy leader, in a 2006 video. He gave the terrorist group political acumen and direction; Osama bin Laden supplied money, prestige and charisma.

item.title: Why Pelosi’s Taiwan Visit Is Raising U.S.-China Tensions
item.description: Beijing has vigorously protested Ms. Pelosi’s trip, warning of unspecified consequences for the United States.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez

item.title: Gentle Into That Good Night? Not Boris Johnson.
item.description: The British prime minister may be leaving Downing Street, but few expect him to cede the spotlight, or abandon the prospect of one day regaining his position.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: “As we’ve seen at Westminster, the herd instinct is powerful,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain said when he announced his resignation last month.

item.title: Living Side by Side, Ukrainian and Russian Sailors Are Tested by War
item.description: Sailors are accustomed to not discussing politics at sea, but the war between the two countries has made that more difficult.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Andrian Kudelya, a 35-year-old sailor from Kyiv, Ukraine, said he would look for jobs where he would not have to work with Russians.

item.title: Ayman al-Zawahri, Killed at 71, Led a Life of Secrecy and Violence
item.description: A radicalized physician, he was seen as the intellectual spine of Osama bin Laden’s terrorist organization and ran it after Bin Laden was killed in 2011.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Martin and Alan Cowell
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ausaf Newspaper for Daily Dawn, via Reuters
item.media:description: Osama bin Laden with Ayman al-Zawahri in 2001.

item.title: To Slow World Hunger, It Will Take More Than Ukrainian Grain Exports
item.description: The departure of a grain-filled vessel from Odesa was hailed as a victory against global hunger. But experts say the crisis is so big that no single advance can reverse it.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Somalia, people left their homes when crops and livestock died in the drought, and walked for days to find food and refuge in a camp for displaced people in Doolow, in the southern Gedo region.

item.title: War Spurs Ukrainian Efforts to Legalize Same-Sex Marriage
item.description: The role of gay soldiers, the lack of legal rights for their partners, and the threat of Russia imposing anti-L.G.B.T. policies have turned the war into a catalyst for change in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid and Dan Bilefsky
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
Servant of the People (Ukrainian Political Party)
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olexander Shadskykh, 23, at the marriage registry building in Kyiv.

item.title: When Home Is a Ferry Ship: An Influx From Ukraine Strains Europe
item.description: Millions have fled Russia’s invasion, but where housing is expensive and scarce, countries like Estonia are paying shipping firms to offer refugees safe but tight quarters.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Marta Giaccone for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lunch time aboard the Isabelle cruise ship, which temporary houses 1,900 Ukrainians.

item.title: Mines, Fires, Rockets: The Ravages of War Bedevil Ukraine’s Farmers
item.description: A deal allowing ships to start carrying grain from Ukraine solved a logistical problem, but it left a more pressing one for Ukrainian farmers: growing and reaping crops in a war zone.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the fields on a recent, sweltering afternoon during the harvest, flames crackled through the stubble of the recently harvested wheat crop of Vasily Tabachnyuk, picking up with gusts of wind.

item.title: Corrections: Aug. 4, 2022
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 4, 2022.

item.title: Taiwan: China’s Military Exercises Could Help It Practice an Attack
item.description: After Nancy Pelosi’s visit, Taiwan braces for three days of Chinese military drills. Beijing calls them a warning, but they may also help its forces hone their skills.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: In Beijing on Wednesday, state television showed footage of what was said to be a Chinese fighter jet near Taiwan.

item.title: Senate Overwhelmingly Votes to Add Sweden and Finland to NATO
item.description: The lopsided bipartisan vote demonstrated broad support in the United States for one of the most significant expansions of the military alliance, amid Russia’s continued assault on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Senate voted to ratify the expansion of NATO.

item.title: As China Plans Drills Circling Taiwan, U.S. Officials Fear a Squeeze Play
item.description: Administration officials say they are hoping China’s military exercises last only a few days, but they are discussing their options if the movements expand into something more.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Taiwanese military participating in a military exercise in Pingtung, Taiwan, last month.

item.title: Switzerland, Leader in Gold Refining, Bans Import of Russian Gold
item.description: The move follows similar bans by the European Union and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

item.title: Welcomed by Taiwan, Pelosi Leaves Rising Tensions With China in Her Wake
item.description: In a high-stakes visit to Taiwan, Ms. Pelosi offered assurances of American support. Taiwan now faces the prospect of Chinese military drills that could violate what it says are its territorial waters.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi visiting Taiwan’s legislature in Taipei on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Builds a Case That Killing of P.O.W.s Was a Russian War Crime
item.description: At a Russian-held prison, graves were dug days before the explosion that killed at least 50 Ukrainian troops held there, Ukrainian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Christiaan Triebert, Kamila Hrabchuk and Stanislav Kozliuk
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Tensions Rise as Pelosi Leaves Taiwan
item.description: Also, Ukraine braces for a Russian attack and Mexico faces an extreme drought.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, met with Taiwan’s president, Tsai Ing-wen, and was presented with an award for outstanding contributions to Taiwan.

item.title: Biden Administration’s Bid to Cap Russia Oil Prices Faces Resistance
item.description: The maritime insurance industry says policing oil transactions is not workable, raising questions about enforcement of a buyers’ cartel.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Ships awaiting entry to ports in the Black Sea near Constanta, Romania. A proposed cap on the price of Russian oil is drawing skepticism.

item.title: On Pelosi’s Taiwan Trip, Europe Largely Stays Out of the Fray
item.description: Europe does not support the independence of Taiwan and recognizes Beijing as the seat of Chinese power. So European leaders were mostly quiet about Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Lithuania was the only European Union member to openly support Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan. Gabrielius Landsbergis, Lithuania’s foreign minister, said on Twitter that she had “opened the door to Taiwan much wider.”

item.title: Pelosi’s widely watched flight to Taipei took a circuitous route. Here’s why.
item.description: Nearly three million people logged onto their computers to try to track Nancy Pelosi’s controversial trip to Taiwan. As it took a different and more circuitous path, many were confused.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s plane arriving at Songshan airport in Taipei, Taiwan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Cairo
item.description: Yasmine El Rashidi, a journalist and novelist, guides readers through Cairo, a city whose presence is so powerful it is “the subject, the object and the main character” of many of its writers.
item.dc:creator: Yasmine El Rashidi

item.title: Taiwan and Ukraine: Two Crises, 5,000 Miles Apart, Are Linked in Complex Ways
item.description: The fear since the start of the war in Ukraine has been that Moscow and Beijing will be driven closer as the United States casts both issues as a struggle between authoritarianism and democracy.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Taipei, Taiwan, rallied in support of Ukraine in May.

item.title: How Bad is the Monkeypox Virus?
item.description: It’s not Covid, but there are good reasons to take precautions.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: An electron microscope image monkeypox virions.

item.title: Pelosi draws crowds as she moves through Taiwan’s capital.
item.dc:creator: John Liu
item.media:description: Demonstrators and spectators turned out in Taipei on Wednesday. The man’s sign reads “Oppose Pelosi’s visit to avoid Taiwan cross-strait war.”

item.title: Map: Where China Plans to Conduct Military Drills Circling Taiwan
item.description: China’s plans to conduct live-fire drills into Taiwan’s territorial seas could mark a new stage of brinkmanship.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and Amy Chang Chien

item.title: Living side by side, Ukrainian and Russian sailors are tested by the war.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Emma Bubola

item.title: Pelosi’s Taiwan Visit Risks Undermining U.S. Efforts With Asian Allies
item.description: The Biden administration has built an economic and diplomatic strategy in Asia to counter China, assuring friendly countries that the U.S. is in the region for the long haul.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, in Taipei, Taiwan, on Wednesday. Her trip is seen by allies of the United States in Asia as an unnecessary provocation.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Nancy Pelosi meets with Taiwan’s president.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan could provoke China at a time when tensions with the U.S. are high.

item.title: Taiwan’s leader, Tsai Ing-wen, has vowed to defend its sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi meeting with President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan at the presidential office in Taipei on Wednesday.

item.title: Corrections: Aug. 3, 2022
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 3, 2022.

item.title: Al-Zawahri’s Death Puts the Focus Back on Al Qaeda
item.description: The terrorist network has lost eight of its top leaders in recent years. But it has more total fighters than it did on Sept. 11, 2001.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Killing of al-Zawahri Stirs Debate Over Biden’s Afghan Strategy
item.description: President Biden now confronts the question of what, if anything, he will do in response to the revelation that the Taliban were again sheltering a leader of Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: The Biden administration has not outlined consequences for the Taliban’s sheltering of Ayman al-Zawahri, Al Qaeda’s leader, who was killed in a drone strike.

item.title: In Visiting Taiwan, Pelosi Capped Three Decades of Challenging China
item.description: From her first days in Congress, the future speaker was willing to confront China’s leaders. As she looked toward her legacy, the California Democrat was not about to back down this time.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan was in keeping with her deep-seated position that China must be held to account for its posture toward Tibet and Hong Kong, as well as its treatment of ethnic minorities and political activists.

item.title: How the C.I.A. Tracked Ayman al-Zawahri, the Leader of Al Qaeda
item.description: The U.S. search for Ayman al-Zawahri had spanned decades. His presence on a balcony at a safe house in Kabul presented an opportunity to strike.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Ayman al-Zawahri, left, listening to Osama bin Laden during a news conference in Khost, Afghanistan, in 1998. Al-Zawahri became Al Qaeda’s leader after Bin Laden’s death.

item.title: In Ukraine, Devastation Spreads as Russia Regroups for New Offensive
item.description: The U.S. has announced $550 million in additional arms for Ukraine as it gears up to defend its eastern regions, which Ukrainian officials have asked civilians to flee before winter.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Peter Baker and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian residents of the frontline town of Bakhmut waited with their bags to be evacuated on Tuesday.

item.title: Pelosi cites ‘America’s determination to preserve democracy.’
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi visiting Taiwan’s legislature in Taipei, the capital, on Wednesday.

item.title: Zelensky Says Civil Partnerships For Same-Sex Couples May Become Legal
item.description: The Ukrainian president said the constitution’s ban on same-sex marriage could not be changed during the war. Calls for equal rights have grown as L.G.B.T.Q. soldiers have joined the fight against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: A Pride parade in Kyiv, Ukraine, last year. The war has spurred efforts to secure equal rights for L.G.B.T.Q. Ukrainians, including the right to marry.

item.title: The Outdoor Cat: Neighborhood Mascot or Menace?
item.description: To some, letting cats roam is unthinkable. To others, so is keeping them inside.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Vanessa Leroy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zeke, an outdoor cat that roams the neighborhood, sits underneath a neighbor's bush in Jamaica Plain, Mass.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: China Plans Drills as Pelosi Arrives in Taiwan
item.description: Also, a U.S. strike kills Al Qaeda’s leader and Trump will face questions under oath.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: China Announces Military Drills Near Taiwan as Pelosi Visits
item.description: China planned live-fire drills that would take place partially inside Taiwan’s territorial waters, escalating already high tensions.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Paul Mozur

item.title: The U.S. Imposes New Sanctions on Russians, Including a Woman Close to Putin.
item.description: Many of the targets are already under sanctions imposed by the European Union and Britain. One is Alina Kabaeva, a former Olympic gymnast believed to be the romantic partner of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: New U.S. sanctions target the Russian oligarch Andrey Guryev, whom the Treasury Department identified as the owner of Witanhurst, said to be the second-biggest residential property in London, after Buckingham Palace.

item.title: Pelosi trip could take U.S.-China acrimony to new heights, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi arriving in Taiwan on Tuesday, becoming the highest-ranking American official to travel there in decades.

item.title: Russia backs China’s stance on Taiwan, calling Pelosi’s visit ‘provocative.’
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Dmitri Peskov, the Kremlin’s spokesman, called Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan “provocative” during a briefing in Moscow on Tuesday before she arrived.

item.title: A Cyberattack Crashes the Website of Taiwan’s Presidential Office
item.description: They resumed normal or near-normal operations after the problems were fixed, the affected agencies said.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, Paul Mozur and Amy Qin

item.title: ‘Taiwan ≠ China’: An island accustomed to China’s threats welcomes Pelosi’s trip.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and John Liu
item.media:credit: Amy Chang Chien/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Lin was one of around 100 pro-unification protesters on Tuesday outside the Grand Hyatt Taipei hotel, where Nancy Pelosi is staying during her visit to Taiwan.

item.title: Pelosi has a history of criticizing China’s human rights record.
item.description: For more than three decades, Ms. Pelosi has criticized China’s policies in Tibet, Hong Kong and other sensitive regions. Chinese officials do not appreciate it.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest over a draft extradition law in 2019 in Hong Kong. Speaker Nancy Pelosi praised the demonstrators as “courageous.”

item.title: As Pelosi touts ‘unwavering’ U.S. commitment to Taiwan, China denounces her visit.
item.description: The trip, the highest-level U.S. visit to the island since 1997, came in the face of strenuous objections from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Amy Chang Chien and Michael D. Shear

item.title: A New Axis?
item.description: With tensions rising in Taiwan, we look at the shared interests of China, Russia and Iran.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin, left, and Xi Jinping in Beijing in February.

item.title: Brittney Griner Back in Russian Court as Lawyers Plead for Leniency
item.description: The case is expected to end with a conviction in the middle of this month, her lawyers say.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner being escorted by a police officer ahead of her hearing in Khimki, outside Moscow, on Tuesday.

item.title: As Pelosi Arrives, Quiet Defiance in Taiwan
item.description: Public nonchalance about the tensions over Nancy Pelosi belies a political reality: Many are tired of China’s threats and crave American support.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Chris Horton and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: News about Speaker Nancy Pelosi on a restaurant’s TV in Taipei, Taiwan, on Monday.

item.title: As a grain shipment heads to Lebanon, fighting intensifies on many fronts.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Razoni, laden with Ukrainian corn, left the Port of Odesa on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The U.S. kills Al Qaeda’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Ayman al-Zawahri, shown in 1998, while in Khost, Afghanistan.

item.title: Ukraine Grain Ship Passes Russia’s Black Sea Blockade
item.description: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a ship loaded with corn sailed out of Odesa, part of a deal officials hope will help ease food shortages around the world.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Razoni, which was laden with corn, leaving Odesa on Monday.

item.title: Manchin Won a Pledge From Democrats to Finish a Contested Pipeline
item.description: To cement the senator’s support for a climate and tax package, party leaders promised to pass a law to complete the line and to prioritize some other fossil fuel projects.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Construction on the Mountain Valley Pipeline, intended to carry natural gas from West Virginia into Virginia, in 2019.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Pelosi’s Planned Taiwan Visit Tests China
item.description: Also, efforts to fight urban heat in Singapore and deadly anti-U.N. protests in Congo.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: A television broadcasting news about Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, at a restaurant in Taipei, Taiwan, on Monday.
